title: Welcome
text:
I am currently a student at SIT (Singapore Institute of Technology). This website serves as a portfolio of my technical projects, data visualization work, and learning reflections.


I have a strong interest in software development and automation. My work often involves building tools that solve real-world problems, such as automating news delivery or analyzing personal data trends.









Project Page: A deep dive into my Tele-Forex-News-Bot, a Node.js application deployed on Render.
Data Visualization: An analysis of my personal fitness and nutrition metrics using Python.
Hobbies: My hobbies and how it relates to my projects.
Reflection: My thoughts on using Generative AI to accelerate development workflows.




Feel free to reach out if you’d like to discuss code, gym stats, or automation projects!

title: Data Visualization
text:
As part of my personal fitness journey, I started collecting data on my daily nutritional intake. The graph below visualizes my caloric consumption over a typical week compared to my maintenance target.



Figure 1: Weekly Caloric Intake vs. Target Goal




The bar chart displays the total calories consumed (blue bars) for each day of the week, from Monday to Sunday. The red dashed line represents my daily caloric target of 2200 kcal. * X-axis: Days of the week. * Y-axis: Total Calories (kcal). * Data Source: Personal food logs recorded via MyFitnessPal.



The Story: I noticed my weight was fluctuating despite “feeling” like I was eating consistently. I decided to visualize the data to find the pattern. The visualization reveals a clear trend: I tend to under-eat on weekdays (Wednesday/Sunday) to “save” calories, but then over-consume significantly on Saturdays (2600 kcal), which disrupts my weekly average.
Rationale for Visualization Choices: * Bar Chart vs. Line Chart: I chose a bar chart because daily intake is a discrete total for that specific day, making it easier to compare the magnitude of each day against the others. * Target Line: Overlaying the red target line provides an immediate “benchmark” for the viewer to see which days were compliant (under/on target) and which were outliers. * Annotations: I added the exact numerical values on top of the bars so the viewer doesn’t have to guess the exact calorie count by looking at the Y-axis.



I used Python’s matplotlib library to generate this chart.
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

days = ['Mon', 'Tue', 'Wed', 'Thu', 'Fri', 'Sat', 'Sun']
intake = [2100, 2250, 1950, 2400, 2150, 2600, 1800]
target = [2200] * 7

plt.bar(days, intake, color='skyblue', label='Actual Intake')
plt.plot(days, target, color='red', linestyle='--', label='Target')
plt.title('Weekly Caloric Intake')
plt.legend()
plt.show()

title: Data Visualization
text:
As part of my personal fitness journey, I started collecting data on my daily nutritional intake. The graph below visualizes my caloric consumption over a typical week compared to my maintenance target.



Figure 1: Weekly Caloric Intake vs. Target Goal




The bar chart displays the total calories consumed (blue bars) for each day of the week, from Monday to Sunday. The red dashed line represents my daily caloric target of 2200 kcal. * X-axis: Days of the week. * Y-axis: Total Calories (kcal). * Data Source: Personal food logs recorded via MyFitnessPal.



The Story: I noticed my weight was fluctuating despite “feeling” like I was eating consistently. I decided to visualize the data to find the pattern. The visualization reveals a clear trend: I tend to under-eat on weekdays (Wednesday/Sunday) to “save” calories, but then over-consume significantly on Saturdays (2600 kcal), which disrupts my weekly average.
Rationale for Visualization Choices: * Bar Chart vs. Line Chart: I chose a bar chart because daily intake is a discrete total for that specific day, making it easier to compare the magnitude of each day against the others. * Target Line: Overlaying the red target line provides an immediate “benchmark” for the viewer to see which days were compliant (under/on target) and which were outliers. * Annotations: I added the exact numerical values on top of the bars so the viewer doesn’t have to guess the exact calorie count by looking at the Y-axis.



I used Python’s matplotlib library to generate this chart.
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

days = ['Mon', 'Tue', 'Wed', 'Thu', 'Fri', 'Sat', 'Sun']
intake = [2100, 2250, 1950, 2400, 2150, 2600, 1800]
target = [2200] * 7

plt.bar(days, intake, color='skyblue', label='Actual Intake')
plt.plot(days, target, color='red', linestyle='--', label='Target')
plt.title('Weekly Caloric Intake')
plt.legend()
plt.show()

title: My Hobbies
text:
Beyond coding and studying, my main passion is fixed-gear cycling (Track bikes). Unlike standard road bikes, a fixed-gear bike has no freewheel—meaning if the bike is moving, the pedals are turning.







I currently ride a Cinelli Vigorelli, a frame known for its aggressive geometry and track heritage.
My Current Setup: * Frame: Cinelli Vigorelli Alu (2018) * Type: Fixed Gear / Track * Riding Style: Urban & Track Training




“Cycling is the closest you can get to flying while remaining on the ground.”

Riding fixed gear offers a unique connection between the rider and the road. It requires constant awareness and physical control, which I find to be the perfect mental reset after a long day of programming.




Fitness & Nutrition: I actively track my macros and training metrics to optimize performance (as seen on my Data Visualization page).
Tech tinkering: I enjoy messing around with automated scripts and bots in my spare time.

title: My Hobbies
text:
I spend my free time exploring…



It helps me relax.
It challenges me technically.


“A hobby is not just a pastime, but a way to recharge.”

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text: For this assessment, I utilized Gemini as my primary Generative AI assistant. I chose this tool because of its strong capability in handling both natural language processing (for content drafting) and code generation (for Python and Markdown formatting).

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text: For this assessment, I utilized Gemini as my primary Generative AI assistant. I chose this tool because of its strong capability in handling both natural language processing (for content drafting) and code generation (for Python and Markdown formatting).

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
How GenAI Assisted Me
The AI played the role of a “Pair Programmer” and content strategist throughout the development of this website.

1. Content Drafting & Structuring
I provided the AI with raw details about my personal projects (such as my Tele-Forex-News-Bot), and it helped me restructure those points into a professional “Project” page. It automatically applied correct Markdown syntax, such as headers, bolding for emphasis, and blockquotes for challenges.


2. Data Visualization
One of the most helpful aspects was in the creation of the Data Visualization page. I asked the AI to help me visualize my fitness tracking data. * It suggested a bar chart combined with a target line to show nutritional consistency. * It generated the actual Python (Matplotlib) code to render the graph, which I then documented on the website.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
Benefits and Challenges







Aspect
Description




Speed
It significantly reduced the time spent on writing boilerplate code (like the YAML configuration).


Clarity
It helped articulate technical concepts (like the Node.js architecture of my bot) more clearly than I could have alone.


Challenge
A challenge was ensuring the specific syntax for Quarto (like image alignment) was correct, as the AI sometimes defaults to standard Markdown.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
Future Application
Going forward, I see GenAI not as a replacement for coding, but as an accelerator. I plan to use it to: 1. Debug Code: Quickly identify syntax errors in my C or Node.js projects. 2. Brainstorm: Generate ideas for features in future software applications.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
Final Thoughts
Using GenAI allowed me to focus more on the content and story of my portfolio rather than getting stuck on the syntax details of web development.

title: Project: Forex News Bot
text:
For this project, I developed the Tele-Forex-News-Bot, an automated tool designed to deliver real-time foreign exchange (Forex) news updates directly to users via Telegram.
The goal was to create a low-latency notification system that helps traders stay updated with market-moving news without constantly refreshing websites.

title: Project: Forex News Bot
text:
For this project, I developed the Tele-Forex-News-Bot, an automated tool designed to deliver real-time foreign exchange (Forex) news updates directly to users via Telegram.
The goal was to create a low-latency notification system that helps traders stay updated with market-moving news without constantly refreshing websites.

title: Project: Forex News Bot
text:
Technical Architecture
I built this application using a modern JavaScript stack and cloud deployment.

Runtime: Node.js
Platform: Telegram Bot API
Deployment: Render (Cloud Application Hosting)
Version Control: Git

View Code on GitHub

Key Features

Automated Fetching: The bot scrapes/fetches financial news from configured sources.
Instant Notifications: Uses the Telegram API to push alerts immediately to the user’s device.
24/7 Uptime: Deployed on Render to ensure the service runs continuously in the background.

title: Project: Forex News Bot
text:
Development Challenges

“One of the main challenges was managing the deployment pipeline on Render to ensure the bot automatically restarted if it crashed.”

I resolved this by configuring the build commands correctly in the Render dashboard and implementing robust error handling in the Node.js scripts to catch API failures gracefully.

title: Project: Forex News Bot
text:
Future Improvements
I plan to add sentiment analysis to the news feeds, allowing the bot to tag news as “Bullish” or “Bearish” automatically.
